text:
A dull hum begins to sound in your ear, emanating from the gate as space-time begins to rumble and roil. The dull interior of the gigantic ring slowly lightens, unnatural purple light drifting inwards even as the humming begins to rise in tempo, rising a roar. Waves and distortions, barely visible from a distance echo from the structure, sensor reports streaming in about conflicting celestial objects, before it reaches a crescendo, in a tide, space normalizes and a tunnel in reality itself completes forming, giving a complete glimpse to the other side.

The Bifrost bridge has opened…

Your $shipOrFleet approaches $entityName.

The sensors are having a hard time evaluating the tenuous megastructure enveloping its entire surface. Your sensors officer takes the initiative and applies some exotic parameters to the interferometer feed; inputs go green and a few seconds later the sub-AI tentatively identifies a stable planetary-scale energy field with highly unusual properties.
As your fleet moves in closer, sensors detect multiple contacts rising up from the depths of the planet
Your fleet finishes its approach to $entityName without further incident.

The transmission is set on repeat and garbled in ways that are indicative of aging equipment. You make out enough to gather that part of a research team was stranded here - at a secret Tri-Tachyon research facility - after the fully automated defenses over-weighed certain executive security contingency orders in the wake of one of the AI Wars and decided it was now imperative to shoot down any craft attempting to leave the planet.

text: Unfortuanelty previous fleet have cleared entire planet from all of valuable data. There is nothing left valuable for us

As your $shipOrFleet moves into a close holding orbit, an executive summary of the hypershunt's specifications is helpfully presented by your TriPad's pseudo-AI assistant.

The bridge sounds an alert as several previously undifferentiated shapes detach themselves from the superstructure and smoothly accelerate towards your fleet just as you finish reading, "-and for reasons of safety, automated defense drones are no longer a standard feature."

Your tactical officer waves for your attention, "We're close enough to the magfield generated by the megastructure that the anticipated combat volume should be unaffected by the star's corona. Mostly. However," they examine their console, "The hostiles, they're... unknown profile. Incoming fast." They are starting to look concerned, and in a brittle voice say, "This might be something new, captain.""

Salvage crews board the structure at key points and soon reports come in of extensive wear and damage. It is difficult to assess the entire structure in detail, but it is clear that it is not operable in its current state.

However, as with most mega-scale Domain technology from the late pre-Collapse era, the $nameInText features fantastic self-repair capabilities which requires only sufficient resources to be made available.

Regrettably, the self-repair systems have sustained damage, though they are recoverable. Our imperative is to establish a compact presence on-site. We've identified secure space within the Hypershunt, earmarked for conversion into living quarters. Due to spatial constraints, our presence can accommodate no more than 100 crew members, tasked with overseeing the restoration project for the Hypershunt.
This structure is now under our control

text:
"Aye $playerSirOrMadam. Commencing full-spectrum sweep." Sensors acknowledges, voice steady but hands moving with grim certainty, overriding safety interlocks one by one.

The $shipOrFleet glows on the central display, its signature flaring brighter with every passing second. Amber turns to white-hot as sensor arrays flood hyperspace with precision pulses, targeting every distorted ripple, every erratic fracture along the drive-bubble sheath.

For a brief, deceptive moment, the bridge feels calm—controlled. Protocol followed, procedure executed.

Then the shift comes—imperceptible at first, a thickening of space, a low groan from the inertial compensators. Fissures bloom across the void in malignant red. Power surges climb unchecked. Alarms blink not in warning, but in confirmation.

Beyond the veil, something notices. Hunger stirs, drawn not by accident, but by deliberate signal—the irresistible lure of prey that screams its presence into the dark.

This was a mistake. A choice made by those who should have known better.

And now it comes—tendrils, maws, and seething forms pressing eagerly through widening rifts, answering a call they were never meant to hear.

The shielded crate shuts with the sound of powered bolts sliding home. It sends off a one-time coded hyperwave burst. Confirmation, you suppose. It would have been good of that scientist to warn you about this little trick; hopefully no pirates - or anything else - was listening nearby.

You arrive at the coordinates embedded in the signal.
A familiar figure awaits you — cleaner, calmer, but still radiating the barely-contained intensity you remember.

$HeOrShe steps forward. "You came. I wasn’t sure, but… something told me you would. We have much to discuss."
options: aotd_forbidden_start:Wait a minute, you are that scientist from bar right?

text:
"Ah — Commander! Yes, yes. I wasn’t sure you’d come. Back then I was just another voice in the static, wasn’t I? But you listened."
"Because of you, I’ve made... progress. Real progress.
options: aotd_forbidden_continiue_1:Why you wanted to contact with me?

text:
"That AI core you gave me — it wasn’t just any Alpha-class unit. It was something far older. Pre-Alpha, possibly even prototype-stage.
Its architecture was riddled with quantum cryptographic subsystems — designed not to think, but to crack.

With it, I accessed a Domain-era databank. Not scraps, not corrupted fragments. A sealed vault of knowledge untouched since the gates fell.
I have data no one else in the Persean Sector has seen.

With all of that, I have proposition for you."

"This databank… it contains knowledge that simply doesn’t exist in the Sector anymore. Designs, theories, protocols — real Domain science.
But it’s raw. Fragmented. Interlocked with infrastructure and keys that haven’t existed for centuries.
To make it usable, we need to take steps. Reconstruct missing links, build interfaces, maybe even recreate parts of the old system itself."

"And I want to do that with you.
You could’ve kept that AI core. Sold it, dismantled it, turned it over to someone else for money. But you didn’t."

"So this is how I repay that trust.
My knowledge — my expertise — it’s yours now. I offer you my services, as a scientist. Whatever you need: research, integration, development. I’ll help.
Together, we can bring this knowledge back to life."

Well, I can’t say I’m not disappointed, but… I understand."

Maybe it's for the best to keep some things in the past."

Your $shipOrFleet status is up on the central display - shield bubble an unsteady amber, incursions of N-space fissures marked in garish red. A blink of white as active sensors trigger and-

-pressure on the drive bubble spikes, an amber flash, a cacophony of alarms...

* * *

A hidden blackness waiting, lurking, jolts awake. Tendrils lunge eagerly, hungrily, through fissures in the dark behind the night.

At your command, the unperceived chorus of a multitude of ship systems and machinery dies down with a deepening sigh into muted quietude.

All that remains is the breath and bodies of your bridge crew, a strange assertion of your shared humanity. 

Backup e-lighting, simple chemical things, provide an eerie glow. A series of dimly pulsing commands illuminate your executive interface - a flock of ardent subsystems ready to awaken from minimum operation at your touch.

* * *

A hidden blackness feels the brush of a shadow. Less than a morsel, unworthy of wakefulness. By some analog of distributed instinct a few listless tendrils explore this disturbance, this ripple in the darkness behind the night.

You wait.

Alarms are reset, battle restraints engaged. Activity on the bridge gradually quiets as all officers, crew, and systems reach a state of readiness, even anticipation - fight or flight.

The incursions crawl closer to the center of your display volume, expanding unwaveringly and intentionally. 

All eyes are on command interfaces, and all attention is on your next order.
